sub_topic: Solving systems of linear equations using block matrices
message_1:
Suppose you're given the following system of equations:

$$\begin{cases} 3x + 2y - z = 7 \\ 2x - 4y + 5z = -1 \\ x + y - z = 2 \end{cases}$$

Use block matrices and solve for $x$, $y$, and $z$.
message_2:
To solve the given system of equations using block matrices, we first write the system in matrix form:

$$\begin{bmatrix} 3 & 2 & -1 \\ 2 & -4 & 5 \\ 1 & 1 & -1 \end{bmatrix} \begin{bmatrix} x \\ y \\ z \end{bmatrix} = \begin{bmatrix} 7 \\ -1 \\ 2 \end{bmatrix}$$

Now, we can write the augmented matrix:

$$\left[\begin{array}{ccc|c} 3 & 2 & -1 & 7 \\ 2 & -4 & 5 & -1 \\ 1 & 1 & -1 & 2 \end{array}\right]$$

We will now perform Gaussian elimination to get the matrix in row-echelon form:

1. Swap row 1 and row 3:

$$\left[\begin{array}{ccc|c} 1 & 1 & -1 & 2 \\ 2 & -4 & 5 & -1 \\ 3 & 2 & -1 & 7 \end{array}\right]$$

2. Replace row 2 with row 2 - 2 * row 1, and row 3 with row 3 - 3 * row 1:

$$\left[\begin{array}{ccc|c} 1 & 1 & -1 & 2 \\ 0 & -6 & 7 & -5 \\ 0 & -1 & 2 & 1 \end{array}\right]$$

3. Multiply row 2 by -1/6 and swap row 2 and row 3:

$$\left[\begin{array}{ccc|c} 1 & 1 & -1 & 2 \\ 0 & 1 & -2 & -1 \\ 0 & -6 & 7 & -5 \end{array}\right]$$

4. Replace row 1 with row 1 - row 2, and row 3 with row 3 + 6 * row 2:

$$\left[\begin{array}{ccc|c} 1 & 0 & 1 & 3 \\ 0 & 1 & -2 & -1 \\ 0 & 0 & -5 & -1 \end{array}\right]$$

5. Multiply row 3 by -1/5:

$$\left[\begin{array}{ccc|c} 1 & 0 & 1 & 3 \\ 0 & 1 & -2 & -1 \\ 0 & 0 & 1 & 1/5 \end{array}\right]$$

6. Replace row 1 with row 1 - row 3, and row 2 with row 2 + 2 * row 3:

$$\left[\begin{array}{ccc|c} 1 & 0 & 0 & 14/5 \\ 0 & 1 & 0 & -3/5 \\ 0 & 0 & 1 & 1/5 \end{array}\right]$$

Now, we have the matrix in row-echelon form, and we can read off the solutions:

$$x = \frac{14}{5}, \quad y = -\frac{3}{5}, \quad z = \frac{1}{5}$$
